data.text:
Oh my God, thatâs when I worked at Seeburg.

TODD L. BURNS

So what is this record?

Tom Moulton

[comments over music] Itâs âI Fall To Piecesâ by Patsy Cline. When I went out to California I lied about my age. To get a driverâs licence in California all you had to do was say, âIâm 20 or 21.â And I was only 17, so I said I was 21 and I was able to get a driverâs licence and that was my ID if I wanted to go to a bar. I wasnât big on drinking anyway. Anyway, I worked for Seeburg, and Seeburg, they made jukeboxes. They had what they call a one-stop meaning that instead of going... If you wanted to buy records from RCA, youâd go to RCA distributor and buy them, then youâd go Columbia, or youâd go to EMI, or youâd go to all these different labels. And they would be like 41 cents. Now, if you went to a one-stop, the records might be 44 cents but youâre paying for the convenience of only going to a one-stop to get all the records you wanted without going to all these different labels. In those days, if you bought a record before it became a hit, say, if you bought 500, youâd get 250 of them free. I was pretty good at that, and thatâs one of those records that I bought and got 250 free and nobody bought it. And then that happened to another record by a Southern guy called Ernie K-Doe called â not Ernie K-Doe, it was Jessie Hill, called âOoh Poo Pah Doo.â And I just thought that was one of the greatest records. Nothing happened.

TODD L. BURNS

So what happened with the company?

Tom Moulton

A year later, because they really reamed me out for that, saying, âOh man, weâve got all this stuff,â and blah-blah-blah. So a year later both those records started to hit. Nobody had the record, we were the only one who had the record, so it worked out, so I thought, âWell, OK, got to move on from here.â

TODD L. BURNS

Where did you move on to?

Tom Moulton

Well, I was fascinated with what they call stereo sound, that was something that was brand new at that time, and I was just fascinated with the realness of it. I mean, mono was like this [gestures] and stereo was this wide, big, beautiful sound and it just had a realism to it. So I worked for a company called Muntz and they developed a playback head or actually a record head/playback head that would record four tracks in the same direction. Thatâs who I worked for and I just wanted to push the sound of stereo because I thought it helped the music so much.

TODD L. BURNS

What time period are we talking about here? This is late â50s or so?

Tom Moulton

Yes.

TODD L. BURNS

And one of the things I find fascinating about the business back then is that they were like, whatever, it costs more to do this or it costs more to buy these records in stereo, so...

Tom Moulton

Oh, that was another thing. What happened, you know I keep thinking it was way back then but it was later, now that I think about it. There was an illness in my family and I had to move back east, so I ended up moving to Boston after everything was straightened out with the family. So I worked for a record store for a while until I was able to get into promotion. They had a distributor that distributed records and I wanted to get into promotion again. So I said, âBut Iâll work for the record store now.â Again, these hits would come by and albums were like $2.98 at that time. God, I feel like thatâs the dark ages, $2.98. But anyway, then stereo was a dollar more, it was $3.98. I was always buying stereo to push it because I thought stereo music was much better than mono. And I remember peeling back a label off a jacket and I said, âOh my God, the Supremes album was recorded in stereo, maybe Iâll order it.â I tried to order it and they said, âNo, that crap donât sell in stereo.â Anyway, we had to buy 25 of it and my boss had a fit when I bought it. He says, âYou better sell every one of those or youâre going to lose your job.â So what did I do? Put it out and started playing it. People would come in and say, âOh, you got the Supremes album?â Yeah, I said, âYou want it mono or stereo?â âWhich is cheaper?â And Iâd be furious. Iâd say, âListen, you want to hear it like this or do you want to hear it like that?â And theyâd go, âOh my God, listen to that!â And Iâm saying, âGod, these people know nothing.â No, I mean, I was just fascinated that the music was so much more alive in stereo. I mean, I really feel like I was a pioneer with some of this stuff because people just didnât know, and I think you have to educate people about things or they donât learn anything. How are they going to know? By the time they find out for themselves, I mean, if theyâre not in the right place at the right time theyâre not going to find out until a long time later.

TODD L. BURNS

You eventually, after this time in Boston, went to Europe for a tiny bit?

Tom Moulton

Yeah.

TODD L. BURNS

What were you doing over there?

Tom Moulton

Nothing. I just wanted to go somewhere different, and I was going to go to France, Germany, where else was I going to go? Holland and Switzerland. So I ended up going to Denmark and I loved it. I said, âMy God, everbody talks soft,â and everybody was nice and nobody had attitudes. Just everybody went out of their way to be so warm. And I said, âGod, Iâd like to move here. I mean, everybodyâs just so nice.â I was never exposed to people like that before, and boy, coming back here, it was horrible. I remember we had to go through customs, through Canada, and they were under martial law for some reason, there was some terrorist or something. This is back in the early â70s now and I remember going through customs and you had all these policemen around and military saying, [harsh] âOpen your bag! Whatâs in there?â And theyâd go shuffle it all up and he said, âOK, next.â And I said, âExcuse me! I had that bag neatly folded. Now God damn it, I can see why people hate Americans so much.â I really felt like I was Danish and I wasnât going to take that treatment from these lousy, loudmouthed Americans. I said, âHey, I had nothing in there, just put it back the way it was.â And I said, âIâm not leaving until you do it.â So this other guy came over, in the military, and I said, âLook, âblah-blah-blahâ, just straighten it out and close the bag.â And I said, âThank you so much.â And then the guy next to me said, âDo you have anything to declare?â âNo, but my bag is very neat.â

[laughter]

I just thought that was so funny. I donât know how we got onto that subject.

TODD L. BURNS

If you loved Denmark so much why did you end up coming back?

Tom Moulton

I had to, the money ran out, you know? But it was funny, I was walking through a park â this is a funny story â I was in a bar and not many people speak English. Iâm probably going to get red when I tell this story because it really is funny. So this guy comes up to me and he says, âViggo Holm.â And I went, âI donât think so.â You donât think thatâs funny, âVe go homeâ? I go: âNo, I donât think so.â And he kept saying, âViggo Holm.â I said, âGet away from me, what the hell are you doing?â I didnât know that was his name. And then Iâm saying, âYou know, âWe go homeâ?â And then Iâm trying to explain to him how I took it. He didnât get it.

TODD L. BURNS

So you went home to America.

[laughter]

Tom Moulton

No, I did not, no. So anyway, I ended up getting to know him because he was really a nice person, and then I look in the phone book, thereâs so many Viggo Holms. I mean, my God, in Denmark it seemed like everybody had the last name Holm. So anyway, he invited me over with some friends to have dinner, so I took a shortcut through the park and I said, âOh my God, I canât believe it. I see this old couple sitting on a bench in the park and there was no one else around.â So I got there and I said, âYou know, I just saw the most amazing thing. There was this old couple sitting in the park.â And theyâre all looking at me. I said, âYeah, but in New York theyâd be dead or mugged by now.â

[laughter]

Thatâs the thing , and they just looked like, âYes?â They just looked like I was in a totally different world.

TODD L. BURNS

So when you got back to that totally different world?

Tom Moulton

I didnât like it, I had a hard time adjusting because...

TODD L. BURNS

What were you doing around that time?

Tom Moulton

What was I doing?

TODD L. BURNS

Work-wise. You said youâd run out of money.

Tom Moulton

Well, I came back and I got a job. You know, I was still modelling. Or actually I didnât model, no, I went to Europe first. Because when I left United Artists thatâs when I quit the record business, and I lost a lot of weight because I broke a tooth in Denmark, but anyway, thatâs not a musical story.

TODD L. BURNS

Well, it ended up being a musical story because if you hadnât become a model...

Tom Moulton

Well yeah, because I realised in the music business youâre constantly, at least if youâre in the promotion end of it, youâre constantly manipulating people. Because youâre trying to get your record played, and youâre conniving, and youâre doing all these different things to get your record played. I just got so sick of doing that. I mean, I just wanted to go and say, âHey, this is a great record. Play it.â But then I had a better idea. If theyâre going to associate me with a good record, why not tell them about somebody elseâs record too? So Iâd always go in there and say, âOh, have you heard this song or that song? Well, I think itâs going to be a hit.â And theyâd always take your advice if it wasnât your record. You know, what did you have to gain from it? And then theyâd say, âHave you got anything of yours?â âActually no, I donât have anything this week. I really donât have anything that competes with those records.â But anyway, then when I did have a good record most of the time I got it on the air because of that. So it worked out well.

TODD L. BURNS

So you were the best manipulator of all.

Tom Moulton

Well no, because theoretically I was doing good. I didnât look at it as...

TODD L. BURNS

Yeah. So youâre back in the United States, modelling. Youâve given up the record industry because you hate the hypocrisy, manipulation.

Tom Moulton

Right.

TODD L. BURNS

But then it sucks you back in.

Tom Moulton

So anyway, at the agency I was at, I mentioned that I used to be in the music business. And they said,âOh, do you know John White?â And I go, âWhoâs that?â And they said, âHeâs the guy over there,â and he was very British sounding. Little did I know, they call that an affect. [imitates britsh accent] âOh, hello.â You know? But anyway, he was a New Yorker but he had this kind of accent, so anyway, he had a place in Fire Island. And they said, âWhy donât you come out and see what itâs like?â And I went, âWow, OK!â

TODD L. BURNS

Sorry, Fire Island, for people who donât know, sort of had a reputation back then. What did you think when someone said, come to Fire Island?

Tom Moulton

Well, actually I didnât hear the reputation. Remember, Fire Islandâs a very, very big place. I think youâre referring to the gay community. I mean, thereâs two areas â I mean, I think of it as a gay community, a lot of people that arenât gay go there â but those two areas. But Fire Island is a tremendous place and thereâs other communities, which I wasnât aware of.

TODD L. BURNS

I just remember reading an interview where you said you werenât sure if you wanted to go out there because it was...

Tom Moulton

Well, I heard little things like that, you know, and I said OK. But I figured since John owned the place and we were at the same agency it was fine. Anyway, they had a thing called âtea danceâ in the afternoon, and I was so fascinated because they were playing soul records and all these white people were dancing to it. I went, âOh my God, I found my people!â I could never understand why I always preferred black music, only because I was able to feel it, and I felt like I was very much an emotional sponge when it came to that kind of music, because it just went inside me and affected the way I felt and the way I reacted to the music. And to find other white people that liked that, that absolutely fascinated me. And so then thatâs when I got the idea. I was watching how they danced and how they would always...

TODD L. BURNS

How did they dance?

Tom Moulton

Well, you know, they were doing what they called shuffle, and the hustle, and basically they were doing one-two-three-four. And I noticed whenever they left the dancefloor they would leave on âoneâ. And this DJ was terrible. You know, the next record would come in and you donât know whether youâre dancing to the last song or trying to move your feet to the new song. And I thought, âWell, there has to be a way to do that smoothly, where youâd be able to build them up where theyâd get excited over the music.â You canât get very excited over a song if itâs only two-and-a-half, three minutes long. So anyway, it took me almost 80 hours to do a 45-minute tape. And I had varispeed, so Iâd start a song and constantly varispeed it so slow you couldnât tell it was getting faster. But your body would react to it because the intensity was picking up. And then the next song would come in, and the next song, so by the time I got to the last song you could peel the people off the ceiling. I mean, they were all worked up, and I just thought that was a fascinating thing to do. So the trick was, I said, âIf they all leave on âoneâ, then the idea is to get them dancing to a song before you got to âoneâ. Then theyâre already dancing to it so theyâre not going to walk off, theyâre just going to go with it.â And thatâs exactly what happened.

TODD L. BURNS

Tell me about putting that tape together. You said it took...

Tom Moulton

80 hours.

TODD L. BURNS

So why did it take 80 hours?

Tom Moulton

Well, because I wanted it to be perfect.

TODD L. BURNS

Can you talk about the construction of the tape?

Tom Moulton

Oh my God! I had a Revox tape machine and it had a little quirk in it. Donât ask me how, but if you had it set up, you EQ it where you get right to the play. And you cue a record and then you hit record when you want it to come in exactly. You would hear the ambience of the song before, so it would sounded like it was a mix rather than what they call âslip cueâ now, I guess they call it. I just didnât want the interruption of another song, I wanted it to actually sound natural â if thatâs the word to use. Anyway, I still remember when I gave him the tape and he said, âDonât give up your day job.â I didnât know what [to say]. I just was so hurt over that because it took me hours to make that. And I was sitting on a bench where the boat comes, because you have to get to Fire Island by a boat, a ferry. So I was sitting there waiting and this fellow said, âAre you okay?â I said, âWhy?â He said, âYou look like you lost your best friend or your dog or something.â I explained my story and said, âJohn didnât like my tape.â And he said, âLook, the guyâs an idiot. I donât do the music but my partner does. If you want Iâll let him hear it.â I said, âOK.â He said, âJust put your name, your phone number. Weâll call you and let you know.â So I gave him the tape and I got a call that following weekend, it was Saturday they called me, and they said they hated it. Absolutely hated it. I didnât know what to do, I was so down over that. I said, âWell, maybe Iâm wrong.â So two oâclock in the morning I get a phone call and thereâs all this noise, these crazy people waking me up. This happened three or four times and finally I just took the phone off the hook. So the next morning, Sunday morning, I get a phone call, âHi Tom, itâs Ron from The Sandpiper. They loved the tape.â I said, âRon, I only gave you one tape. You told me they hated it.â He said, âNo, no, no. On Friday nights they want to unwind because theyâve been working all week in the city. They want familiarity, they want things they know. Youâve got so much new music on there that they donât know. So on Saturday theyâve had the day on the beach and now theyâre ready to dance, ready to move, and they want something new.â So Saturday night they loved it. Thatâs how I got involved, that led to going into mixing in a studio, so itâs fascinating how I got drawn back into the business like that.

TODD L. BURNS

You were going around to record companies, because they asked you to make more tapes, and looking for instrumentals.

Tom Moulton

Right.

TODD L. BURNS

And then you somehow got involved in mixing tunes.

Tom Moulton

Well, someone asked me if I could â I did something experimental with it and they said, âCould you do that in a studio?â I said, âIâm not that familiar with it but Iâll do it the best I can.â And, of course, everything I was doing was exactly different than how you make a record. So I said, âI want to do this and this and this...â âWell, thatâs not how itâs done.â And I go, âYeah, but I want to do it that way.â

TODD L. BURNS

What were some of those things that you were doing differently?

Tom Moulton

Well, like, I would drop out the vocal and then I would raise the strings. And they would go, âThat sounds weird.â I said, âIt sounds weird to you but it donât sound weird to me.â But it seemed like I was fighting all the time. One thing Iâve learned living this long is, if you want to do something and you believe in it, donât let anybody say, âThatâs not the way itâs done.â Because you got to follow what you feel, and thatâs where you get into that place where when you achieve something, you achieved it because you believe in it even though everybody tries to say, âNo, no, thatâs not the way to do it.â You do it. Then if it fails you say, fine, but at least you tried. So thatâs why I like to encourage people, if they have something they want to try in music, try it, donât listen to anybody else, just try it.

TODD L. BURNS

When you turned in your first mix, so they were like, âThis is not how itâs done, you canât do it this wayâ?

Tom Moulton

Yeah, well, they hated it. The group hated it. And then when they were on Soul Train, when it was a #1 record, âYeah, thatâs the way we recorded it.â Oh, I was so angry. [laughs] âYeah, we did it that way, thatâs the way we did it.â

TODD L. BURNS

What did you do to the record, and what record are we talking about?

Tom Moulton

âDo It (âTil Youâre Satisfied),â B.T. Express.

TODD L. BURNS

Should we maybe listen to it?

Tom Moulton

Oh, you have that?

TODD L. BURNS

Yeah, I think so.

Tom Moulton

Oh, OK. This wasnât planned, he was playing other songs before this. Thatâs why Iâm surprised he has that.

(music: B.T. Express â âDo It (âTil Youâre Satisfied)â)

Tom Moulton

[comments over music] And white people loved it.

TODD L. BURNS

So what was it that the group hated?

Tom Moulton

When the organ comes in. They said, âYou cut out my vocal.â I said, âYeah, but it sounds like the guy got so hot feeling the groove that he hit the organ.â This song was so suggestive, thatâs what I loved about it. See I think in this country they really tried to keep white music for white people and black music for black people. I could never understand that. You know, itâs like the South versus the North. In the South they accept black music because thatâs the kind of music they play down there, but up here they just... I donât know, I could never understand it. [organ comes in] That part, damn, itâs just so... Itâs what we call the shiii... [laughs] I notice a lot of people tapping their feet, and thatâs exactly what itâs supposed to do, shake your bones.

TODD L. BURNS

So how long is this song?

Tom Moulton

Not long enough. I think itâs probably five thirty-five.

TODD L. BURNS

Seems like a lot of your records are five minutes and thirty-five seconds.

Tom Moulton

Well, itâs like, when youâre successful at something, itâs like saying, well, maybe thatâs a good luck charm. I didnât plan on making them. Well, maybe when it came to the fade I might rush it a little bit so it gets to five thirty- five. But no, I was quite successful with five thirty-five.

TODD L. BURNS

For a pop song itâs quite long, right? And was there a lot of feedback from people again saying you canât put this on radio?

Tom Moulton

Well, that was the whole thing. When I went to master it the mastering engineer said, âThereâs too much bass, thereâs too much low end. Youâre not going to get any level.â That was with the edited version. So when I went into the studio I had to remix it because of that. Say I said, âOK, letâs get rid of the low end on of the kick drum and put more of a knock.â See, as long you had that kick in there, I think that had a lot to do with changing the kick to almost where it sounds like a low snare rather than a kick drum.

TODD L. BURNS

So that was a pretty big chart success.

Tom Moulton

Yeah, and the only place from there to go is down. You know, when you go here and then you go, well, what are you going to follow it up with? Well, then the follow up was Al Downing and Gloria Gaynor, so...

TODD L. BURNS

So, not a bad second and third act.

Tom Moulton

Right. But again, all these things when people say, âOh my God, you created the break and you did the 12" and you did this...â I say, âYeah, but theyâre all accidents, every single one of them.â Because that wasnât the plan, to create. And like creating the break, a song modulated, so I had to get everything out that was musical. Then I would bring the conga and the hi-hat just so it would carry the rhythm. Then when I bring the bass in or a Fender Rhodes, people say, âOh yeah, the song modulates twice.â Well, it doesnât, it modulates once, but because you do 16 bars of just percussion, they donât remember what key itâs in. So then it sounds like it modulates again.

TODD L. BURNS

Letâs talk about one of those accidents, the 12". You go in to mix a record, to put it on an acetate, rather. And theyâre out of the normal 7"s.

Tom Moulton

Theyâre out of 7" blanks. See what I would do is, Iâd be in Philadelphia four nights a week, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday. And Thursday I never slept for like 12 years, because Iâd come right straight back to New York and it would be Friday morning. Then Iâd go to Media Sounds, which is where I mastered the records. And they didnât have any 7" blanks. I always believe that when you present a record company with something youâve done, you ought to present it in its highest form. So if you play it like itâs going to sound on a record, then you have everything working in your favour. So they didnât have any, all they had was 12". I said, âOh my God, what am I going to do? OK, just cut it.â It was cut in spec, meaning you had this disc that was this big [gestures] and you had this much groove in the middle. And I go, âWhat is that? I canât give that to somebody.â I said, âCan you start it from there and spread the grooves, just make it where it looks likes thereâs more?â They said, âYeah, we got to raise the level then.â I said, âOK, just raise the level.â And of course it was cut plus eight. I said, âOh my God!â And then I listened to it and I went to the record company. They didnât know what the hell to do with that. Then I realised, I said, âHey, if my record sounds that much better than everybody elseâs, Iâm not going to tell anybody.â See, the promotion man was coming out in me again, the advantage. Thatâs how it started. People say, âOh my God, you created the 12",â and I went, âNo, they didnât have any 7" blanks.â

[laughter]

TODD L. BURNS

It took a long time. Again, this kind of goes back to the mono/stereo situation, it took a long time for companies to get used to the idea of a 12" and want to make them.

Tom Moulton

Well, like I said, people donât like to change. I can understand why, itâs the unknown that they donât like. You like the security of what you know. Itâs difficult, you always have to prove it for them to do it. So they were making just DJ promo copies of 12"s originally, and Ken Cayre who owns Salsoul Records, said, âYou know, Iâm going to make a commercial 12".â I said, âI donât know, I donât know if itâs going to sell or not.â Well, believe me, it sold. And then everybody started making those 12"s. But people are afraid, they donât want to try something new. You always feel like youâre a pioneer when you step outside or cross that line, because youâre all by yourself. Thatâs why I said earlier, if you have something you believe in, at least develop it to where someone can say, âI donât like it.â Or, âI love it.â At least get to that place.
